newsitem.title: USA: Russian treasures truck moves to Washington embassy.
newsitem.headline: Russian treasures truck moves to Washington embassy.

text.p: An exhibition of priceless treasures from Russia's imperial past that were stranded in a truck outside a museum for six days because of a legal wrangle were moved to the Russian Embassy on Tuesday.
But no decision had been reached on the ultimate fate of the collection, including the Romanov czars' crown jewels which remained in the museum's vault.

The collection, including art works, costumes and some of the world's biggest gems, was due to be shown in several U.S. cities thoughout this year, starting with a successful show at Washington's Corcoran Gallery of Art that has just ended.
But Russia now says it wants the treasures back for Moscow's 850th birthday celebration in May, according to the Corcoran.
The American organisers of the exhibition had refused to deliver them to the Russian Embassy, citing a contract with the Russian government.

"Our agreement to release the truck is a good faith effort on the part of the Russian Embassy and the American-Russian Cultural Cooperation Foundation," the group's chairman James Symington said in a statement.
A spokeswoman for the foundation, which raised $550,000 to mount the exhibition, said no decision had been reached on the final disposition of the jewels.
Corcoran Gallery president and director David Levy has locked away the Romanov gems in a vault and is sitting tight until he gets a court order or a written agreement about where they go next.

The moving van hired to take the exhibition to Houston for the next stop on a planned tour, had been parked on a side street near the gallery since last Wednesday, blocked in round-the-clock with cars manned by drivers from the Russian Embassy.
The exhibition, "Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Imperial Court" drew over 80,000 visitors during its stay at the Corcoran.
Symington attributed the standoff to a dispute over revenue, not to Moscow's need for the jewels back home.

He said the deal with Russia's Culture ministry was to split revenues after expenses were paid, but said Russian officials were now telling him that that arrangement was not acceptable. "It doesn't satisfy them," Symington said Monday.
But John Millian, a lawyer retained by the Russian Embassy, denied that profits were the motive.
The State Department said a Russian official was on his way to Washington in an attempt to end the standoff.
